Robert E. Kahn

Biography

Robert Elliot Kahn, born on 23rd December 1938, is an American Internet pioneer and IT researcher. He was born in New York and studied electrical engineering at the City College of New York. In 1972 he joined the IPTO (Information Processing Techniques Office) within DARPA, the U.S. agency responsible for the development of new technologies for military use. He had also an important role in the development of ARPANET as he helped to develop the TCP/IP transmission protocols.

Research

Kahn, while working on a satellite network project, came up with the idea of a new Transmission Protocol for the ARPANET that could replace that time's current protocol, the NCP. Vinton Cerf helped him with the development of the TCP and, by 1973, they created a first version.
He then started a research and development program funded by the U.S. federal government, the strategic Computing Initiative, focused on the research about machine intelligence.
Kahn also co-founded with Vinton Cerf the Internet Society, a nonprofit organization with the aim to promote the development and evolution of the internet for the benefit of everyone.

Awards

Award Year
SIGCOMM Award 1993
National Medal of Technology 1997
Charles Stark Draper Prize 2001
Prince of Asturias Award 2002
Turing Award 2004
Japan Prize 2008
Turing Award 2004

In memory of A.M. Turing
